Award.AwardTitle: Biomechanics Across Scales: A Combined Computational-Theoretical-Experimental Approach
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project the PIs will develop, validate and implement a computational-theoretical-experimental framework, referred to as Cellular Particle Dynamics (CPD), to quantitatively relate biomechanical properties at the cell level to those at the multicellular and tissue level. Within this formalism a cell, considered as a continuum material object with defined volume and adaptive shape, is coarse-grained into a finite number of equal volume elements. Each such element is represented by a point-like Cellular Particle (CP) situated at the center of the volume element. Interactions between the CPs determine their effective size (same as the size of the volume element they represent), as well as their dynamical behavior. Cell and multicellular level biomechanical properties (e.g. viscosities, elastic moduli) will be determined through the combined use of experiments and the proposed theory of continuum elastic and viscous media. The same biomechanical properties will also be measured computationally using the CPD framework, and results expressed in terms of parameters characterizing CPs and their interactions, the CPD parameters. Comparison of experiments and simulations will quantitatively relate CPD parameters to the biomechanical properties of both cells and multicellular assemblies. Once the CPD parameters have experimentally been calibrated, the formalism will provide a systematic framework to predict the time evolution of complex multicellular systems during shape-changing biomechanical transformations. As an application, the PIs will use the novel framework to guide ongoing efforts to fabricate tubular, lumen-containing functional organ structures (contractile vascular grafts). At present no systematic framework exists to analyze biomechanical processes that involve multiple scales, resulting from the combination of individual cell behavior and collective cell rearrangements and this project will fill this gap. Beyond this intellectual challenge that the proposal will address the project will contribute to the urgent practical societal need of fabricating functional replacement tissue and organ modules. The graduate students involved in these activities will be exposed to multiple scientific disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the project was to develop, validate and implement a computational-theoretical-experimental framework, referred to as Cellular Particle Dynamics (CPD), which is capable of describing and predicting the shape evolution in time of three-dimensional (3D) multicellular systems during their biomechanical relaxation. CPD turned out to be an effective method for describing and predicting the outcome of post-printing structure formation in 3D bioprinting.  

In the CPD formalism a cell, regarded as a continuum material object with defined volume and adaptive shape, is coarse-grained into a finite number of equal volume elements. Each such element is represented by a point-like cellular particle (CP) situated at the center of the volume element. The time evolution of a multi-cellular system is governed by equations of motions of the interacting CPs. These equations contain model parameters, corresponding to specific cell types that are determined from simple "calibration experiments" (e.g. fusion of two multicellular spheroids). Theory provides the link between the CPD model parameters employed in CPD simulations and the corresponding calibration experiments. Thus, once the CPD model parameters are determined, the CPD formalism can predict the post-printing time evolution of a complex bioprinted 3D multicellular structure.

The intellectual merit of the project is emphasized by its main outcomes, summarized as follows: (1) We have developed a general continuum theory for describing the fusion of spherical and cylindrical aggregates ('bioink' particles). The theory accounts for the change in volume (and length in case of cylindrical aggregates) during the fusion process, as it happens in general in experiments. In CPD simulations the volume is conserved. (2) We have determined the CPD parameters corresponding to human skin fibroblast (HSF) cells by performing and comparing calibration experiments with CPD simulations of the fusion of two spherical and cylindrical aggregates. (3) We have demonstrated that volume conserving CPD simulations can in fact describe and predict the corresponding fusion experiments during which the volume of the system decreases in time. (4) We have formulated and tested a novel procedure to predict the outcome of an arbitrary post-printing fusion process directly from the corresponding CPD simulation. (5) We have explained and demonstrated that the post-printing fusion process is considerably faster when using cylindrical instead of spheroidal bioink particles. This result has considerable practical implication for extrusion bioprinting. For example (see Figure), CPD simulations predict that the post-printing tube formation (e.g., formation of blood vessel) using HSF cylindrical aggregates takes only ~12 hours compared to ~22 hours when using spheroidal aggregates. [In the figure, cells from adjacent bioink particles are colored differently (green and red) to emphasize their lack of mixing during fusion.]   

Broader impacts of the project include: (1) CPD in its current form is suitable to provide guidance and optimization for bioprinting 3D tissue constructs (e.g., much needed replacement tissue and organ modules) in industrial settings. This is important because at present bioprinting is time consuming, expensive and is largely based on trial and error. (2) The graduate students involved in the project were exposed to multiple scientific disciplines (physics, biology, chemistry, engineering) by working together on the different but organically related aspects of the project. The graduate assistant working on theoretical modeling and CPD simulations was exposed and introduced to most parts of the experimental work. Similarly, the experimentalist graduate research assistant became familiar with CPD simulations and theoretical modeling.

The results from this projec...

CPD turned out to be an effective method for describing and predicting the outcome of post-printing structure formation in 3D bioprinting. In the CPD formalism a cell, regarded as a continuum material object with defined volume and adaptive shape, is coarse-grained into a finite number of equal volume elements. The time evolution of a multi-cellular system is governed by equations of motions of the interacting CPs. Theory provides the link between the CPD model parameters employed in CPD simulations and the corresponding calibration experiments. [In the figure, cells from adjacent bioink particles are colored differently (green and red) to emphasize their lack of mixing during fusion.] Broader impacts of the project include: (1) CPD in its current form is suitable to provide guidance and optimization for bioprinting 3D tissue constructs (e.g., much needed replacement tissue and organ modules) in industrial settings. This is important because at present bioprinting is time consuming, expensive and is largely based on trial and error. The graduate assistant working on theoretical modeling and CPD simulations was exposed and introduced to most parts of the experimental work. Similarly, the experimentalist graduate research assistant became familiar with CPD simulations and theoretical modeling.
